title: Why are many popular musical instrument companies Japanese? - Quora

response.answer_text: Some of it is happenstance. They started later than their European counterparts. That means they were able to look at the procedures without previous bias or attachment, and pick what worked best. There are also cultural aspects—attention to detail, ingrained apprentice system. Two words are useful in encapsulating this: kata (型) and dou/michi (道). Many people are familiar with martial arts kata, sometimes translated as “forms.” A more expansive definition would be “distillation of movement into efficient form.” Japanese are equipped to learn new things and then transmit them as kata. The Suzuki method of teaching violin is one product of this mindset. The creation of kata also facilitates quality control. The term -do is familiar to many from “aikido” and “bushido”. Practice of any discipline becomes a way of life, with every action streamlined to facilitate performance. Western musical instruments also held special significance as a symbol of modernity. The Meiji Revolution was a time when the Japanese government was engaged in full-scale modernization, which was equated with Westernization. Mastering a Western craft was almost a patriotic imperative!
